narrative_events.description: The antagonist is introduced in a state of confinement.
The Brahman naively trusts the Tiger's false promises and releases him.
The Tiger immediately breaks his promise and threatens to eat his rescuer.
The first judge (Tree) rules against the Brahman, citing humanity's own ingratitude.
The second judge (Buffalo) rules against the Brahman, citing human cruelty.
The Jackal feigns confusion to buy time and accompanies the Brahman back to the Tiger.
The Jackal pretends to be incredibly stupid, frustrating the Tiger into reenacting the scene.
The third judge (Road) confirms that gratitude is nonexistent.
The Tiger re-enters the cage to prove his point, and the Jackal locks him in.

motif_type: Motif J873.2: J873.2. Clever jackal covers up his clumsiness in catching cows by saying he was running to and fro because he was looking for the fattest calf. (J. The wise and the foolish. > J200–J1099. Wise and unwise conduct. > J850–J899. Consolation in misfortune.)

Motif J2131.5.6: J2131.5.6. Jackal's head caught in pot of blue dye. Animals make him king, but detect him from his cry and turn him out. (J. The wise and the foolish. > J1700–J2749. Fools (and other unwise persons). > J2050–J2199. Absurd short-sightedness.)

Motif J512.13: J512.13. Jackal accidentally made king but joins other jackals in howling at night. Killed. (J. The wise and the foolish. > J200–J1099. Wise and unwise conduct. > J500–J599. Prudence and Discretion.)
Motif J2413.8: J2413.8. Jackal tries to roar like lion at elephant. Is killed. (J. The wise and the foolish. > J1700–J2749. Fools (and other unwise persons). > J2400–J2449. Foolish imitation.)

Motif K565.2: K565.2. Jackal entrapped in elephant's carcass tells passing God to show his magic power by making it rain. Elephant's hide swells; jackal escapes. (K. Deceptions. > K500–K699. Escape by deception.)

Motif J1791.4: J1791.4. Dog drops his meat for the reflection. Crossing a stream with meat in his mouth he sees his reflection; thinking it another dog with meat he dives for it and loses his meat. (J. The wise and the foolish. > J1700–J2749. Fools (and other unwise persons). > J1750–J1849. Absurd misunderstandings. > J1750–J1809. One thing mistaken for another.)

textSpan.text: a tiger was caught in a trap. He tried in vain to get out through the bars, and rolled and bit with rage and grief when he failed.

propp_functions.evidence: The antagonist is introduced in a state of confinement.

textSpan.text:
By chance a poor Brahman came by. "Let me out of this cage, oh pious one!" cried the tiger.
"Nay, my friend," replied the Brahman mildly, "you would probably eat me if I did."
"Not at all!" swore the tiger with many oaths; "on the contrary, I should be for ever grateful, and serve you as a slave!"
Now when the tiger sobbed and sighed and wept and swore, the pious Brahman's heart softened, and at last he consented to open the door of the cage.

propp_functions.evidence: The Brahman naively trusts the Tiger's false promises and releases him.

textSpan.text: Out popped the tiger, and, seizing the poor man, cried, "What a fool you are! What is to prevent my eating you now, for after being cooped up so long I am just terribly hungry!"

propp_functions.evidence: The Tiger immediately breaks his promise and threatens to eat his rescuer.

textSpan.text:
On this the Brahman turned back sorrowfully, and on the way he met a jackal, who called out, "Why, what's the matter, Mr. Brahman? You look as miserable as a fish out of water!"
The Brahman told him all that had occurred. "How very confusing!" said the jackal, when the recital was ended; "would you mind telling me over again, for everything has got so mixed up?"
The Brahman told it all over again, but the jackal shook his head in a distracted sort of way, and still could not understand.
"It's very odd," said he, sadly, "but it all seems to go in at one ear and out at the other! I will go to the place where it all happened, and then perhaps I shall be able to give a judgment."

propp_functions.evidence: The Jackal feigns confusion to buy time and accompanies the Brahman back to the Tiger.
